document.masterDocTitle: A New Record of Brittle Star Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea) from Southwestern Japan, with Notes on its Bioluminescence

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A New Record of Brittle Star Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha (Echinodermata: Ophiuroidea) from Southwestern Japan, with Notes on its Bioluminescence

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Misaki Marine Biological Station, Department of Science, The University of Tokyo, 1024 Koajiro, Miura, Kanagawa 238 - 0225, Japan E-mail: mokanishi @ tezuru-mozuru. com & Corresponding author
International Center for Island Studies, Kagoshima University, 15 - 1 - 6 F Naze-Minatomachi, Amami, Kagoshima 894 - 0026, Japan

subSubSection.paragraph:
Superorder
Ophintegrida O’Hara, Hugall, Thuy, Stöhr, and Martynov, 2017
Order
Amphilepidida O’Hara, Hugall, Thuy, Stöhr, and Martynov, 2017
Suborder
Ophiopsilina Matsumoto, 1915
Superfamily
Ophiopsiloidea Matsumoto, 1915
Family
Ophiopsilidae Matsumoto, 1915
Genus
Ophiopsila Forbes, 1843
[New standard Japanese genus name: Toranoo-kumohitodezoku]
Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha
H. L. Clark, 1915
[New standard Japanese name: Kin-habu-toranoo-kumo hitode] ( Figs 2–8 )

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. Sampling location of
Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha
(star symbol).

subSubSection.paragraph:
A single specimen (NSMT E-13189) was anaesthetized in a 10% aqueous solution of magnesium chloride, then fixed in 99% ethanol. Another single specimen (NSMT E-13190) was directly immersed in 99% ethanol without anesthetization. Photographs were taken during anaesthetisation to prevent long arms from winding vertically, and fixation of NSMT E-13189. An arm of NSMT E-13189 was dissected to remove internal ossicles using domestic bleach (approximately 5% sodium hypochlorite solution), washed in deionised water, dried in air and mounted on SEM stubs using double-sided conductive tape. The preparations were sputter-coated with gold-palladium, examined and photographed with a Jeol JSM 5510LV SEM of the Misaki Marine Biological Station of The University of Tokyo (MMBS). Both specimens were deposited in the National Museum of Nature and Science (NSMT). Morphological terminology used in this study follows
Stöhr et al. (2012)
, Okanishi and Fujita (2018b) , and Hendler (2018) . Terminologies of oral papillae were used as sensu lato (hereafter s.l. ) in Hendler (2018) and were mainly determined based on ontogenetic and anatomical observations. In this study, we did not observe any ontogenetic series and did not dissect mouth ossicles to prevent destruction of discs of the specimens. Thus, we marked “?” for these ossicles which we are not sure ( Fig. 3D ). Systematics used in this study follows
O’Hara et al. (2018)
and
Ophiopsila polyacantha H. L. Clark, 1915: 297
, 298, pl. 14, figs 6, 7; H. L. Clark 1918: 329 ; Koehler 1930: 209 .

Material examined.
NSMT E-13189: one specimen , Kedomi , Kakeromajima island , Amami-oshima island , Kagoshima Prefecture , southwestern Japan , depth approximately
15 m
, SCUBA diving, collected by T
. Fujii, 26 September 2019 .
NSMT E-13190: one specimen , same locality as NSMT E-13189,
16.7 m
,
4 February 2020
.

Diagnosis. Disc surface entirely covered by thick skin; two flat oral papillae s.l. ; oral shields oval, longer than wide; dorsal arm plates hexagonal in proximal portion of arms; arm spines long and flat, no more than 11 in number on proximal portion of arm; adradial tentacle scale narrow and long; arms approximately 18 times longer than disc diameter; vertebrae with perforation on distal portion of arm.
Arms. Five, approximately 255 mm long, approximately 3.3 mm wide and 3.4 mm high in proximal portion, square in cross section. Arms gradually tapering distally ( Fig. 2C, D ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 2.
Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha
, living, in situ (A, B), anesthetized (C, D) and fixed (E–H) states of a smaller specimen (A, G, H; NSMT E-13190) and a larger specimen (B–F; NSMT E-13189). A, with burrowed disc and extended arms; B, exposed from sand ground, dorsal view; C, E, G, dorsal views; D, F, H, ventral views. Scale bars=1 cm.

subSubSection.paragraph: On proximal to middle portion of the arms, ventral arm plates slightly wider than long, distal and proximal sides straight and both lateral sides concave, contiguous ( Figs 3F, G , 8M–P ). Dorsal arm plates oblong, slightly wider than long, distal edge slightly rounded, contiguous ( Fig. 8G–J ). External shape of lateral arm plates mostly concealed by arm spines, separated by dorsal and ventral arm plates ( Figs 3F, G , 4A, B ; see detailed morphological description below). On distal portion of arms, ventral arm plates long, concave on both lateral and distal sides, convex on proximal side ( Figs 4H , 8Q, R ). Dorsal arm plates longer than wide, oval, and pointed proximally ( Figs 4C , 8K, L ). Lateral arm plates bearing arm spines; on proximal portion of arm, 11 long, flat and broad spines, dorsal- and ventral-most spines the longest, approximately 1.5 to 2 times longer than corresponding arm segment, third from ventral-most spines shortest, slightly shorter than the corresponding arm segment ( Figs 3F , 4A, D ). On middle portion, 5 or 6 spines, long and flat, ventral-most spine longest, approximately 1.5 times longer than the corresponding arm segment, spine length gradually decreasing towards dorsal side, exceeding half the length of corresponding arm segment ( Figs 3G , 4B, E ). On distal portion of arms, two spiniform arm spines, ventral-most spine longest, almost same length as corresponding arm segment and dorsal-most spine half length of corresponding arm segment ( Figs 3H , 4C, F ). Tentacles long, approximately 3 to 4 times longer than corresponding arm segment, with fine protrusions arranged in multiple longitudinal lines ( Fig. 4F ). Tentacle scales two, adradial one longer, thin, spiniform and covered by skin, approximately twice as long as corresponding arm segment on proximal portion of arm and approximately same length of the corresponding arm segment on middle to distal arm ( Fig. 3F–H ); outer tentacle scale shorter, flat and broad, approximately half the length of corresponding arm segment on proximal portion of arm with length decreasing to one-quarter of the length of corresponding arm segment distally ( Fig. 3F–H ). Detailed descriptions of ossicles are provided below.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 3.
Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha
(NSMT E-13189): A, dorsal disc; B, dorsal central part of disc; C, dorsal peripheral part of disc, arrowheads indicate internal edges of radial shields; D, jaws; E, lateral interradial part of disc; F–H, oral views of arms, proximal (F), middle (G) and distal (H) portions. Abbreviations: AdS, adradial shield; AS, arm spine; ASS, adoral shield spine; GS, genital slit; IP, infradental papilla; OS, oral shield; ORS, oral ridge spine; TS, tentacle scale; VAP, ventral arm plate. Scale bars=1 mm.

Fig. 4.
Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha
(NSMT E-13189): A–C, dorsal views of arms, proximal (A), middle (B) and distal (C) portions; D–F, lateral views of arms, proximal (D), middle (E) and distal (F) portions. Arrows indicate orientations: do, dorsal side; v, ventral side. Arrowheads indicate arm spines. Abbreviations: DAP, dorsal arm plate; T, tentacle; TS, tentacle scale. Scale bars=1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description of ossicle morphology (NSMT E-13189). Vertebrae with zygospondylus articulation, large dorsal and ventral muscle flanges on both distal and proximal sides ( Figs 5A, B, F, G , 6D, E ). Surfaces of lateral saddle smooth, with no special ornamentation ( Figs 5D, E , 6B, C ). On proximal side, dorsal muscle flanges wider than ventral muscle flanges in proximal and middle portion of arm and on distal portion of arm, ventral muscle flanges slightly narrower than dorsal muscle flanges ( Figs 5B, G , 6D ), and on distal side, width of both muscle flanges almost the same ( Figs 5A, F , 6E ). Longitudinal deep furrows on both dorsal and ventral sides ( Figs 5C, D , 6A, B , 7F, G ). Transverse furrow on proximal portion of the arm ( Fig. 5D ). Channels for passages of lateral canals unrecognizable on ventral furrow ( Figs 5C , 6A, F ). Depression for tentacles located on lateral distal side of the vertebra ( Figs 5C, E , 6A, C , 7A ).

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 5.
Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha
(NSMT E-13189), SEM photographs of vertebrae from proximal (A–E) and middle (F, G) portions of arms. A, F, distal views; B, G, proximal views; C, ventral view; D, dorsal view; E, lateral view. Arrowheads indicate orientation: do, dorsal side; dis, distal side; pro, proximal side; v, ventral side. Abbreviations: DF, dorsal muscle flange; DT, depression for tentacle; LaS, lateral saddle; LoF, longitudinal furrow; TrF, transverse furrow; VF, ventral muscle flange. Scale bars=100µm.

Fig. 6.
Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha
(NSMT E-13189), SEM photographs of vertebrae from middle (A–C) and distal (D–G) portions of arms. A, F, ventral views; B, G, dorsal views; C, lateral view; D, proximal view; E, distal view. Arrowheads indicate orientation: do, dorsal side; dis, distal side; pro, proximal side; v, ventral side. Abbreviations: DF, dorsal muscle flange; DT, depression for tentacle; H, hole; LaS, lateral saddle; LoF, longitudinal furrow; VF, ventral muscle flange. Scale bars=100µm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Color. In life, the anesthesia did not change the color ( Fig. 2A–D ). Dorsal periphery of disc and radial shields generally pale grey, with patchy patterns of dark brown and yellow ( Figs 2C , 3A ). Arms basically pearl white, with yellow transverse bands, that are 2 arm segments in thickness, separated by 2 to 5 arm segments in an irregular sequence ( Figs 2 , 4 ). Additionally, the yellow bands are flanked both proximally and distally by brown transverse bands that are 1 arm segment in thickness. Between the brown bands, there are arm segments of varying brown pigmentation giving the appearance of brown longitudinal and transverse bands more proximally, and brown transverse bands more distally ( Figs 2 , 3G, H , 4 ). Ventral disc creamy white with patchy patterns of dark brown on oral frames and annular dark brown bands on ventral arms like those on dorsal side ( Figs 2D , 3D–H ). The living color of arm tips of the smaller specimen (NSMT E-13190) is almost the same as the larger specimen ( Fig. 2A ; NSMT E-13189). But color of the remaining area of the smaller specimen is unknown.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 7.
Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha
(NSMT E-13189), SEM photographs of arm ossicles from distal portion (A, H–J), proximal portion (B–D, K, L) and middle portion (E–G): A, vertebra, lateral view; B–J, lateral arm plates, external views (B, E, H), internal views, arrowheads indicate perforations (C, F, I) and distal views (D, G, J); K, L, arm spines, ventral most (K) and middle (L) one. Arrowheads indicate orientations: ba, basal side; dis, distal side; do, dorsal side, ex, external side; v, ventral side; pro, proximal side. Abbreviations: DL, dorsal lobe; DT, depression for tentacle; K, knob; MO, muscle opening; NO, nerve opening; R, ridge; TN, tentacle notch; VL, ventral lobe. Scale bars=100µm.

Fig. 8.
Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha
(NSMT E-13189), SEM photographs of arm ossicles: A–C, arm spines from middle (A, B) and distal (C) portion of arms, ventral most (A, C) and middle (B) one; D–F, adradial tentacle scales, from proximal (D), middle (E) and distal (F) portion of arms; G–L, dorsal arm plate from proximal (G, H), middle (I, J) and distal (K, L) portion of arms, internal (G, J, L) and external (H, I, K) views; M–R, ventral arm plates from proximal (M, N), middle (O, P) and distal (Q, R) portion of arms, internal (M, O, Q) and external (N, P, R) views. Arrowheads indicate orientations: ba, basal side; dis, distal side; ex, external side; pro, proximal side. Scale bars=100 µm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Variation. Some morphological variation was observed in the two examined specimens. The larger specimen [NSMT E-13189: disc diameter (d.d.)= 14.3 mm ] has up to 11 arm spines on the proximal portion of the arm, whereas the smaller specimen (NSMT E-13190: d.d.=7.0 mm) has up to 7 arm spines. Of these arm spines on each lateral arm plates, the longest spines are the dorsal- and ventral-most in the larger specimen, while in the smaller specimen, the ventral-most arm spine is the longest but the length decreases toward the dorsal side.

Distribution.
Ophiopsila polyacantha
is known from the Strait of Macassar, Borneo Bank, Indonesia , approximately 60 m depth ( type locality; H. L. Clark 1915 ); Singapore ( Koehler 1930 ); Kedomi, central Kakeromajima island, Amami-oshima island group, Kagoshima Prefecture , southwestern Japan , approximately 15 m depth (this study).

Habitat. Both specimens (NSMT E-13189 and NSMT E-13190) of
Ophiopsila cf. polyacantha
were collected in sandy bottoms, with buried disc and arms extended and strongly waving into the water column at night time ( Fig. 2A, B ).

The morphology of our examined specimens, in particular, their characteristic coloration is almost identical to that of
O. polyacantha
from Indonesia .

Since the coloration has often been considered an important diagnostic character in the taxonomy of ophiuroids ( e.g. , A. M. Clark and Rowe 1971 ; Irimura and Yoshino 1999 ), our examined specimens should be closely compared to
O. polyacantha
. There is a difference in the number of arm spines between
O. polyacantha
and our examined specimens when comparing individuals of the same size: 11 in
O. polyacantha
(d.d.=7.0 mm), while 7 in our examined specimen (d.d.=7.0 mm; NSMT E-13190). However, the larger specimen we examined has 11 arm spines (d.d.= 14.3 mm ; NSMT E-13189). This suggests that for the genus
Ophiopsila
at least for our examined specimens, the number of arm spines, which has historically been utilized important for taxonomy of
Ophiopsila ,
varies with growth. Thus the stability of this character should be carefully examined, while also collecting data on variation in other species. This also raises the possibility that our examined specimens are one variation form of
O. polyacantha
and should be identified as this species.

The original description of
O. polyacantha
was detailed (H. L. Clark 1915 ), so the morphological comparison could be made as described above, but the type locality of
O. polyacantha
, Indonesia , is more than 4,000 km away from Japan . Thus, it is possible that
O. polyacantha
is genetically differentiated even if it is similar in morphology, and the possibility that our examined specimens represent an undescribed species or subspecies cannot yet be precluded. In this study, the specimens were tentatively identified as
O. cf. polyacantha
, because of the issues, for example of not having DNA analysis done, still to be addressed.

Some species of the genus
Ophiopsila
,
O. brevisquama Koehler, 1930
,
O. multipapillata Guille and Jangoux, 1978
,
O. novaezealandiae Baker, 1974
;
O. guineensis Koehler, 1930
,
O. platispina Koehler, 1930
and
O. seminuda A. M. Clark, 1952
are resemble to our examined specimens in having arm spines which are all flat on proximal portion of the arm. The examined two specimens differs in (1) the covering of the disc, (2) number and shape of oral papillae s.l. , (3) shape of dorsal arm plate on the proximal portion of the arms, (4) shape of adradial tentacle scales ( Koehler 1930 ; A. M. Clark 1952 ; Baker 1974 ; Guille and Jangoux 1978 ) as follows:

(1) Disc covering: Disc of our examined specimens are covered only by thick skin. Those of
O. novaezealandiae
,
O. seminuda , O. guineensis
and
O. platispina
are covered by scales, and that of
O. brevisquama
is covered by small granules. The disc of the holotype of
O. multipapillata
was cast off and no additional specimens of this species have been recorded.

(2) Oral papillae s.l. : On each side of the ventral edge of oral plate, two oral papillae s.l. (not including oral ridge spine) are present in our examined specimens,
O. brevisquama , O. guineensis , O. seminuda
and
O. platispina
. In contrast, there are 6 or 7 oral papillae s.l. in
O. multipapillata
, and 3 to 5 in
O. novaezealandiae .

(3) Dorsal arm plate: Hexagonal in our examined specimens and
O. quineensis ,
square in
O. platispina , O. multipapillata
and
O. brevisquama ,
and oblong (longitudinally long) in
O. novazealandiae
and
O. seminuda .

(4) Tentacle scales: Adradial tentacle scales of our examined specimens,
O. brevisquama , O. multipapillata , O. novaezealandiae ,
and
O. seminuda
are narrow, cylindrical and long. On the other hand, they are long and flat in
O. guineensis ,
and short and broad in
O. platispina .

Length of arm of
O. cf. polyacantha
exceeds approximately 18 times disc diameter, a feature also of
O. xmasilluminans
. However, the oral shields, dorsal arm plates and ventral arm plates on proximal portion of arms are oval, hexagonal and octagonal in
O. cf. polyacantha
. In contrast, these are diamond-shaped, square and oblong, laterally concave, in
O. xmasilluminans
. Additionally,
O. cf. polyacantha
possess continuous holes on vertebrae on distal portion of arms, but these are absent in
O. xmasilluminans
.
O. cf. polyacantha
has black and yellow conspicuous spots and alternating bands on disc and arms ( Fig. 2 ), but
O. xmasilluminans
has yellow concentric bands and green band on disc and arms (
Okanishi et al. 2019
).

We obtained only two individuals in this study and the comparative data of
Ophiopsila
for DNA analysis were not available on GenBank. Therefore, in order to clarify the taxonomy of the
O. cf. polyacantha
and allied species, further specimens should be collected from a wide range of regions, including the type locality of
O. polyacantha
, and taxonomic studies, including DNA analysis, should be carried out.

The specimens described herein are clearly morphologically different from the two species of
Ophiopsila
previously recorded in Japan ,
O. pantherina
and
O. squamifera
. They therefore represent a new record species of
Ophiopsila
for Japan .

The Japanese name is formed as a compound of “Kinhabu” (meaning “golden pit viper”). “Toranoo-kumohitode” (originated from Japanese genus name of
Ophiopsila
), referring to vivid color patterns of
O. cf. polyacantha
, which reminds us of the yellow and white color pattern of the Amami Islands variant of the Ryukyu Islands endemic pit viper
Protobothrops flavoviridis (Hallowell, 1861)
, locally known as “Kin-habu”.

Ecological note. Our video observations reveal that this species flashes its arms when touched by metal forceps (Supplementary Movie 1). We did not measure the spectrum, but the bioluminescence color was green as in other species of
Ophiopsila
(
O. aranea Forbes, 1843
,
O. californica A. H. Clark, 1921
,
O. pantherina ,
O. riseii Lütken, 1859
and
O. xmasilluminans
; see Brehm and Morin 1977 ; Shimomura 1986 ; Grober 1988 ; Vanderlinden and Mallefet 2004 ;
Woolsey et al. 2013
;
Okanishi et al. 2019
). Sand burrowing behavior of
O. cf. polyacantha
is similar to
O. xmasilluminans
and different from another known sand burrowing species,
O. pantherina
(
Woolsey et al. 2013
;
Okanishi et al. 2019
) in that the former two species extend only the distal portions of arms into the water ( Fig. 2A ). Considering that the known ecological features of ophiopsilid species include sand-burrowing and/or bioluminescence, these might be regarded as a general feature in this genus. Further in situ ecological observations of living animals are needed, to reveal details of habitat and behavior. The accumulation of such research will make a significant contribution to the understanding of further characterize species diversity of ophiuroids.
